sentences: Chrisette Michele Payne (born December 8, 1982) is an American R&B and soul singer.
section: N/A

sentences: She won a Grammy Award for Best Urban/Alternative Performance in 2009 for her song "Be OK" (featuring will.i.am).
section: N/A

sentences: She was previously signed to Motown Records, Capitol Records, and Caroline Distribution but was dropped from her label in 2017.
section: N/A

sentences: In the same year, Michele announced plans to release new music independently through her own label, Rich Hipster.
section: N/A
== Early life ==

sentences: Early life ==
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Michele was born in Central Islip, New York, and grew up in Patchogue.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Her father was a sociologist and her mother a psychologist.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Michele led gospel choirs in high school.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: She attended Five Towns College in Dix Hills, New York, and graduated with a vocal performance degree.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Her grandmother is Jamaican.

section: == Music career == | === 2006–2008: Musical beginnings and I Am ===

sentences: Michele has been featured on several hip hop albums, such as The Game's LAX, on the song "Let Us Live".
section: == Music career == | === 2006–2008: Musical beginnings and I Am ===

sentences: On Jay-Z's Kingdom Come, she is appears on the second single, "Lost One", while on Nas' Hip Hop Is Dead, she is featured three times: on the album's second single "Can't Forget About You", the Kanye West-produced "Still Dreaming", and the final track, "Hope".
section: == Music career == | === 2006–2008: Musical beginnings and I Am ===

sentences: She also appeared on the bonus track "Slow Down" from Ghostface Killah's The Big Doe Rehab.
section: == Music career == | === 2006–2008: Musical beginnings and I Am ===

sentences: Michele's debut album, I Am, was released on June 18, 2007.
section: == Music career == | === 2006–2008: Musical beginnings and I Am ===

sentences: The song "Your Joy" was released on iTunes as a free single of the week.
section: == Music career == | === 2006–2008: Musical beginnings and I Am ===

sentences: The album spawned four singles: "If I Have My Way", "Best of Me", "Be OK", and "Love Is You".

section: == Music career == | === 2006–2008: Musical beginnings and I Am ===

sentences: , "If I Have My Way", charted at number 24 on the US Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart.

sentences: "Best of Me" charted on the US Hot Adult Contemporary Tracks at number 21.
section: == Music career == | === 2006–2008: Musical beginnings and I Am ===

sentences: In December 2007, "Be OK" was released as the third single, charting at number 64 on the US Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart.
section: == Music career == | === 2006–2008: Musical beginnings and I Am ===

sentences: In 2008, "Love Is You" was released as the album's fourth and final single; it reached number 90 on the US Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart.
section: == Music career == | === 2006–2008: Musical beginnings and I Am ===

sentences: In 2008, Michele appeared on the track "Rising Up" from the Roots' album Rising Down.
section: == Music career == | === 2006–2008: Musical beginnings and I Am ===

sentences: Michele guest starred as herself in The CW's Girlfriends, in the episode entitled "What's Black-a-Lackin'?", which originally aired on February 11, 2008.
section: == Music career == | === 2006–2008: Musical beginnings and I Am ===

sentences: She also wrote a song for Tyler Perry's House of Payne, titled "I've Gotta Love Jones".
section: == Music career == | === 2006–2008: Musical beginnings and I Am ===

sentences: From May to July 2008, Michele embarked on a nationwide co-headlining tour with fellow soul singer Raheem DeVaughn called the Art of Love Tour; Solange Knowles served as the opening act.

sentences: In September 2008, Michele performed twice at the Evening of Stars: A Tribute to Patti LaBelle.

== Controversy ==

sentences: Controversy ==
section: == Controversy ==

sentences: In January 2017, media outlets reported that Michele would perform at the inauguration of Donald Trump.
section: == Controversy ==

sentences: This was met with backlash on social media, prompting Michele to respond via an open letter on Twitter, stating that she had intended her performance to serve as a bridge between Trump supporters and opponents.
section: == Controversy ==

sentences: Author Aliya S. King published a response to the singer's letter on BET, expressing disappointment with Michele's choice to perform and felt like her letter was a "cop-out".
section: == Controversy ==

sentences: Michele was initially supposed to perform at the Make America Great Again!
section: == Controversy ==

sentences: Welcome Celebration held the day prior to the inauguration, but did not perform and instead played at one of the inaugural balls the following day.
section: == Controversy ==

sentences: In response to her performing, Spike Lee removed Michele's song "Black Girl Magic" from his upcoming Netflix series She's Gotta Have It.
section: == Controversy ==

sentences: Subsequent to the performance, Michele announced the release of her poetry album No Political Genius.
section: == Controversy ==
